message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased bleeding during circumcision, family history of bleeding complications, and prolonged PTT suggest a diagnosis of Hemophilia A, which is a deficiency in clotting factor VIII. Von Willebrand disease and Bernard-Soulier syndrome also cause bleeding disorders, but they do not typically present with prolonged PTT. Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a platelet disorder and would not affect coagulation factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased bleeding during circumcision along with the scattered bruises suggests a bleeding disorder. The prolonged PTT is indicative of a factor deficiency and among the options, Hemophilia A is the most likely diagnosis. Von Willebrand disease may have an abnormal PTT but also presents with abnormal bleeding time. Glanzmann thrombasthenia and Bernard-Soulier syndrome both have normal coagulation studies but present with abnormal platelet function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged PTT and history of bleeding suggest a diagnosis of Hemophilia A, which is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects clotting factor VIII. Von Willebrand disease would present with a prolonged bleeding time, but the PTT would be normal. Glanzmann thrombasthenia and Bernard-Soulier syndrome are platelet disorders, which would not cause a prolonged PTT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of bleeding complications, scattered bruises, and prolonged PTT, indicating a bleeding disorder involving the intrinsic pathway. Among the options, Hemophilia A is the most likely diagnosis, which is caused by deficiency of clotting factor VIII. Von Willebrand disease and Bernard-Soulier syndrome are platelet disorders and Glanzmann thrombasthenia is caused by a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa, which is not consistent with the laboratory results.

We refer to the Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy's prolonged PTT (partial thromboplastin time) suggests a clotting factor deficiency, which is seen in Hemophilia A. Of note, the other options result in normal coagulation times. The scattered bruises on his lower extremities are also consistent with Hemophilia A, as individuals with this condition may experience spontaneous bleeds into their joints and soft tissues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged PTT and the history of bleeding complications in the family suggest Hemophilia A, an X-linked recessive disorder that affects clotting factor VIII. Von Willebrand disease can also cause prolonged bleeding but is unlikely given the normal platelet count. Glanzmann thrombasthenia and Bernard-Soulier syndrome are also bleeding disorders but are rare and have different laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of increased bleeding during circumcision and the familial bleeding history suggest a bleeding disorder. The prolonged PTT and normal platelet count suggest a factor deficiency, which is consistent with Hemophilia A. Von Willebrand disease is associated with increased bleeding time and abnormal platelet function. Glanzmann thrombasthenia and Bernard-Soulier syndrome are rare platelet function disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of increased bleeding during circumcision and a family history of bleeding complications suggest a bleeding disorder inherited from the mother's X chromosome. Among the options, only Hemophilia A fits this pattern. The prolonged PTT also supports this diagnosis as it is a common finding in Hemophilia A. Von Willebrand disease can also cause bleeding, but it would not explain the prolonged PTT. Glanzmann thrombasthenia and Bernard-Soulier syndrome are both platelet disorders, which would not explain the increased bleeding during circumcision.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged PTT and bleeding history indicate a coagulation disorder. The lab results suggest that the boy has hemophilia A, which is characterized by a deficiency in factor VIII. Van Willebrand disease would present with prolonged bleeding time but not necessarily with prolonged PTT. Glanzmann thrombasthenia and Bernard-Soulier syndrome present platelet dysfunction, but this patient's platelet count is normal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of increased bleeding during circumcision, family history of bleeding complications, and prolonged PTT suggest Hemophilia A, which is a genetic disorder that impairs blood clotting. Von Willebrand disease presents with similar symptoms but usually has normal PT and PTT. Glanzmann thrombasthenia and Bernard-Soulier syndrome are also rare genetic disorders that affect platelet function, but they do not affect blood coagulation factors.
